Kind of late, Ill probably post again tomorrow, but was screening for the first time in a while, came across two names that look kind of interesting, not sure if anyone here follows them or has any insight NVMI Nova Ltd. designs, develops, produces, and sells process control systems used in the manufacture of semiconductors in Israel, Taiwan, the United States, China, Korea, and internationally. Its product portfolio includes a set of metrology platforms for dimensional, films, and materials and chemical metrology measurements for process control for various semiconductor manufacturing process steps, including lithography, etch, chemical mechanical planarization, deposition, electrochemical plating, and advanced packaging. Latest investor presentation looks solid, but just not sure how much of their revenue is from China and if there is any risk there. APPF The company provides a cloudbased platform that enables users to automate and optimize common workflows tools that assist with leasing, maintenance, and accounting and other technology and services offered by third parties. It offers AppFolio Property Manager Core, a platform that provides the basic functionalities required to operate a property management business, as well as serves as a system of record AppFolio Property Manager Plus, which offers housing management, student housing management, complex accounting, leasing insights, largescale operations support, rolebased permissions, stack integrations, and enhanced customer support services AppFolio Property Manager Max offers customer relationship management functionality, field customization, customer database functionality, and customer success management services and AppFolio Investment Manager, a software that provides investment management, asset management, and relationship management solutions. If Crox didnt buy HD the stock would probably be 300 right now from buying back 13 of their shares instead and having no debt. But it is what it is, cant change the past. Outside of the poor decision to pay so much for HD, the business is still strong and they are positioning Hey Dude for positive impact long term. They are focusing on DTC for Hey Dude similar to Crox which is a strategy that has increased gross margins and brand loyaltyengagement and to me is a better measure of consumer demand. The of revenue thats DTC for Hey Dude has gone from about 30 to nearly 44 TTM. DTC revenue is only down about 9 while the big majority of HDs revenue drops are from wholesalers. With Hey Dudes branding it makes way more sense for them to focus on digital marketingsales and DTC. Their strategy is not off it will just take time after they pretty much completely reset the Hey Dude strategy a year ago. My biggest gripe with CROX right now is the ballooning SGA expenses. I hope that gets sorted out because they had it down to about 27 of revenue but now its gone back up to 34 of revenue. That needs to slow down, which I think it will. The combination of Hey Dude stabilizing, SGA growth slowing, and a reduced interest expense could give CROX a huge profit boost even without much revenue growth from the crocs brand. Those things are really masking the big gross margin gains over this same period. The bears are constantly waiting for Crocs brand to fall and prove its a fad and the Bulls are waiting for Hey Dude to stop contracting so much and start recovering but the results just kind of keep happening somewhere in the middle. Enough in either direction that you can convince yourself of whatever you want. I increased my CROX share count by a measly 3 today, will probably buy more if it drops another 4 or 5. My long term thesis in the business model of Crox hasnt really changed since I first bought shares in 2020.

MCO Moodys raised its earnings outlook after reporting a jump in profit and revenue for the third quarter amid a rise in transactional revenue. The creditratings and research company said Tuesday it saw a profit 534 million, or 2.93 a share, compared with 389 million, or 2.11 a share, in the yearago period. Adjusted EPS came in at 3.21, above analyst views of 2.87, taken from FactSet. Revenue came in at 1.81 billion, compared with 1.47 billion. Analysts were expecting 1.71 billion, according to a FactSet consensus. The company said transactional revenue grew 70, reflecting heightened activity from infrequent issuers across all lines of business. Moodys Investors Service revenue rose 41 to 1.0 billion, while the Analytics division was up 7 at 831 million. Looking forward, the company raised adjusted EPS guidance for 2024 to between 11.90 and 12.10, from its previous range of 11.00 to 11.40.

SHW earnings were pretty poorly received and sending ripples through the building industry. Mortgage rates are actually not going down, however, if they did go down it makes new houses cheaper and helps builders. If mortgage rates were to go down again, builders would see a boon. Odd lots just did a show on mortgage rates. Basically, its hard for rates to drop when investors know that there will be a refi rush as soon as rates drop. Great listen if you get the chance. I sold my DHI position about a month ago because of the changing dynamics.

Not sure if thats what they said, but one thing Ive called out here also just my opinion, is that lower rates will actually hurt the builders, since lower rates could unlock more used inventory. Historically used homes make up a vast majority of the housing market and because of the high rates and low inventory, new homes actually have been selling at higher rates. Also, new home builders can offer things like mortgage buy downs to draw people in. We are still going to need to build a ton of housing, just as rates go lower in the future and more used inventory becomes available, people will probably buy less new homes. Not saying home builders are a bad investment, just my fear is that theyve hit their peak in terms how much units they historically move. This spring, new home sales are a more important part of the market than they would be in a more typical year, says Lisa Sturtevant, chief economist for Bright MLS. In April, new singlefamily home sales were about 14 of total home sales nationwide. Typically, sales of new singlefamily homes account for less than 10 of all sales transactions, and the last time the new home share was this high was back in 2005.

The company is experiencing massive turnover and due to this cant convert their backlog into realized revenue. Clinical trials require extensive personnel in the startup and active monitoring phase. Every time someone quits, it kneecaps the entire process. A lot of this turnover is due to poor salaries compared to the industry average and the new Return to Office policy. I attended a seminar on the state of the clinical research industry last year where they talked about turnover rates. Industry average is about 25 a year. Last I heard, Medpace was around 4045. There is going to be plenty of business in the clinical research industry, but if Medpace cant get its turnover problem under control, they wont be able to cash in.

Its not one year thats the problem, inflation compounds on previous years. Beyond that, the governments presentation of inflation is inaccurate versus real costs, more often than not. The CPI was 4.7 in 2021, 8 in 2022 and 4.1 in 2023. But lets be real here, we all know prices have increased more than 16.8 in that timeframe. This is especially true when you look at the cost of housing, insurance, food, automobiles, etc. Your example of a sandwich costing 3 more isnt an accurate representation of the true cost of inflation. Even if you accept the governments numbers, which are woefully inaccurate, you still have to accept that inflation compounds on existing inflation. The cost of that sandwich you mentioned, taking the lowest possible numbers, costs almost 17 more than it did a few years ago. This is unsustainable. I dont want anyone to lose their job but higher unemployment for a few years is a better result than our country becoming Argentina or Zimbabwe.

My skepticism comes more from how surprisingly poor the major gold companies fundamentals are compared to the midtier and junior miners. I did a fairly extensive inspection of the sector back in September, running their balance sheets through the CPA database Ive brought up a few times here. If theres one thing I learned as a buyside analyst, its you cant trust the company balance sheet as presented. There are a lot of vagueness and optionality in GAAP standards that leads to companies producing incomparable 10Qs. Not only are the likes of FNV, KGC, GOLD, WPM, NEM, etc. overpriced compared to smaller companies along several valuation metrics, but theyre also less efficient in asset usage and have weaker earnings projections YoY percentage wise as well. The high premium they demand for margin of safety doesnt seem worthwhile when thats the only thing being priced in. Without an exploitable asymmetry in public valuation versus underthehood performance, I struggle to classify them as deals.

ASML assembled and sells lithography machines. These machines range anywhere from older DUV or immersion equipment in the tens of million, to their latest EUV EXE5000 machines which will sell at over 350 million each. For TSMC, Intel, and Samsung to procure a large amount of these machines, they need to open up multiple new fabs, secure enough customer demand, AND invest billions of dollars to procure a number of these EUV machines. ASMLs bread and butter is DUV their servicing line but the growth story comes from their extremely dominant position in lithography. Their growth will always be lumpy as a result of the capital demands imposed on their supplierscustomers, but it is slowly changing as servicing increases on these machines, and EUV begins to display the companys pricing power. The issue at hand is that many industries are going through a downturn, and the pull forward many of us thought would come from automotive and industrials has been delayed. The AI supercycle can only do so much, which is why I only bought heavily at a reasonable valuation of under 240 billion. You remain confused in the delay of growth because you do not understand ASMLs business.

Its an interesting point. For what its worth, I dont think of FNV as a deal, per say. Just a really solid longerterm company thats got a few potential catalysts. I guess my stance is based on the question, Why buy a gold stock over holding physical gold? The metal has no counterparty risk and no exogenous threats can depreciate its value. Youll never have a Victoria Gold situation where your investment is wiped out by one bad day or a legal decision in its jurisdiction. Since gold as an asset fluctuates so violently throughout the decades, the companies are not stable longterm investments either. The big ones have regularly lost 7090 of their stock value at the nadir of cycles and stayed there for years. There are two main justifications IMO Arbitrage between the current price and its current worthfuture potential. According to whatever personal thesis you have regarding golds future price, the disparity should widen appropriately. At heart its value investing and you wait while investors reprice the company accordingly. The passive leverage inherent in a gold companys operations. For the right companies, a 20 rise in golds value can result in 3x profit margins and 4x FCF. With that philosophy, youre treating it as a growth company. With the exception of Agnico Eagle and Northern Star, the big companies dont fit the GARP profile and theyre way too expensive to be value plays. In terms of capital efficiency, some of the junior miners run circles around them I think there are at least 45 with triple digit returns on capitalassets while the biggest companies are stuck between 10 and negative levels. This isnt due to bad management e.g. FNV has a stellar team but their asset portfolios and how regional regulations costs are creating high AISC barriers. Right now, the largecap royalty companies are stuck with a lot of suboptimal mines in jurisdictions that are expensive to operate in. Thats the big impetus behind their recent MA plays. However, most of those have run by the looks of their charts. Still not badly priced though.... RGLD is around 16x PE with a projected 50 EPS increase next year. With its main projects coming online, SANDs EPS will triple in 2025 and compress the multiple down to 89x. I think they have a lot of room to run, and theyre not even the best in their field.

It might be a value trap....or it could be a really interesting royalty play. I recall my first impression was that it was not worth investing in for the backend of 2024. Granite Ridge management had announced plans to bump up the development capex budget by 60 million and the acquisitions capex budget by 25 million, with the investment bearing fruit in early 2025. They were guiding towards doubledigit growth in Q1 Q2 2025 as opposed to mid and high singledigit from sellside. While thats encouraging if one had bought in during 2023, it probably means restricted FCF for Q3 Q4 and an uptick in credit utilization to 7585 of their facility. My price target was, uh checks backlog 7.507.75. I didnt see any discussion about controlling distribution or extending royalty rights to other asset classes, which caps their upside.

Thanks for your insight. Ive been trying to learn how to evaluate some businesses outside my current comfort level, so its nice to see how others look at those businesses. I really appreciate your feedback.

He must be very focused on this metric...since it is so critical... Nice try. You know as well as I do thats a trick question. There is no meaningful volume change in BRK.A. exchange volume since June, and there never has been since the preGFC era. May had the highest average exchange rate in 16 years at 13k that doesnt even reach 1 of all 1.5 million outstanding Class A shares which have not materially changed in 40 years. A significant percentage of that volume consisted of buying back shares too. You can see the historical paucity of volume right here As Class A shares were intended for founding investors and management, they will always have a far lower outstanding shareexchange volume ratio than common stock. This is no different than preferred shares. The comparison is a hilarious false equivalence, especially when BRK.B is fairly healthy in this department.

I just see it falling rapidly today. Its down 2.8. Thats a volatile tech stock and while the company has done extraordinarily well over time, theres been a lot of large declines in that name over the years to get to where it is today. In the shorterterm though, Im concerned that theres a lot of people who are newer to investing who regard declines like this as something that results in considering whether to own the stock. Daytoday volatility like this even if theres not news is sort of the price of admission to owning something like NVDA. If you own something like NVDA for a long enough time youre going to probably see another large drawdown wasnt that long ago when it was down 65 from the 2021 top to the 2022 bottom before the AI theme started up. An off day or rotationflows out of technology might easily be a down 2 day for something like NVDA. There is negative news, but Im not selling technology based upon that. The whole market is down and unless you have names that are beneficiaries or things that manage to bounce, many names are going to be down on a day like today. I dont mean this as a bullishbearishwhatever post, just saying that 2.8 decline in NVDA is something that people have to get used to if theyre going to own growth stocks for any material length of time. If your thesis changes on the name itself, then reconsider owning but selling it solely because its down 2.8 off some broader negative news? I wouldnt recommend it. The market isnt really down much at all a 10 decline used to be viewed as a healthy correction but if it does go further South then you have your shopping list and look for opportunities.

But port fees factor into freight rates. So is the argument that Eastern ports cant simply raise port fees? They can raise port fees. But which ones would they choose to raise? Dockage? Wharfage? Terminal handling? Or would they pass on the costs to container shipping companies, whom the ILA charges with exploiting the Red Sea blockade with exorbitant container rates?

If this happens, it would be really beneficial for American manufacturing. As production is increasingly automated, energy prices have an outsized impact on the cost of production. The concern that I have with mega cap tech and energy is AMZN is buying a nuclear powered data center from TLN, MSFT is starting three mile island or part of it back up again in 2028 wa 20 year deal, ORCL is talking about a massive data center powered by multiple reactors and Im sure GOOGMETA will jump in are there other industries that are going to seek to secure their own power needs if this becomes enough of a scramble? Youre already seeing concern over residential power supply in some areas with data centers popping up and it seems like were in early innings of this intended buildout. It will also realistically take a long time for these projects to come online a lot can happen in the meantime. Id like to think that prices will somehow come down because of this, but more likely think that theyre going up. Was an interview late last year with former Fidelity manager Jeff Vinik talking about how he thinks electrification is going to be one of the big themes of the next decade and that electricity prices are going up 50 over the next 10 years. Clearly, mega cap tech wants to spend, has the ability to and while there is some skepticism there is nothing material at this point. If you build it they will come and they probably will, but if the AI bubble fadesunderwhelmswhatever and massive capacity is built youre not going to want to own tech for a while. Not an applestoapples comparison, but there were at least a few large life science companies that indicated that added covid capacity could be repurposed for other things and that there was demand to meet that. There was not. Those names have yet to get back to 2021 levels and in some cases 2020 levels. And yes, I am long the AI theme power theme.

Large retailers and just about the whole world that has to pay Visa MC hates the duopoly and thinks there needs to be more players and competition. The argument being they keep making money handoverfist sitting without any real innovation. There have been recent attempts to make businesses happy as well as competition through the COF DFS merger That all said, the last class action lawsuit against Visa MC has been ongoing basically now for 2 decades and still not complete. Theyve basically prepared for the liability and its a small footnote that has no impact on results. Washington and courts move VERY, VERY slowly. Generally a bet for politicians or regulators to end up doing nothing is a pretty good bet.

An antitrust case is a concern, yes what the end result is going to be nobody knows. In 2021 their attempt to buy Plaid was denied on antitrust grounds at that point was becoming clear that Visa was getting big enough that growth is going to have to be developed internally, they werent going to be allowed to buy anything material and this separate case is not surprising.

The 20082009 crash would have seen TQQQ drop around 92 at its bottom according to backtests as it didnt exist at the time. The 2000 dotcom crash would of been a lot worse, I believe 99 peak to trough. Although leveraged ETFs can offer much better returns, timing really is everything. A severe crash just after purchasing could leave you worse off 510 years later than if you just bought a non leveraged etf. Also, individual risk tolerance is a big factor. A lot of people think theyll be ok when markets crash, but they totally arent and are often tempted to sell at the worst times high fear, bottom of the market. This is heightened with leveraged products. Imagine seeing a 100k portfolio turn into 8000! Ive bought small amounts of leveraged etfs during corrections no more than 10 of my portfolio, but thats enough for me. You might want to check out the LETF sub, quite a lot of useful information and strategies there.

Just took a deep dive into VivoPower International PLC VVPR and heres what I found Financial Health? Not great. The company has a high net debt and negative EBITDA a bit concerning. Viability is shaky too. Theyre burning cash faster than theyre making it, which isnt sustainable. When it comes to Market Position, theyve got some exciting projects in renewable energy but havent been able to turn those into strong revenue growth yet. Revenue Quality is unstable, think project delays and supply chain issues bogging things down. Profitability? Practically nonexistent at the moment. Heavy losses with deep negative margins. The Outlook is mixed. Some potential growth opportunities, but theyve got serious existing hurdles to clear. Their Track Record shows volatile stock performance and underperformance in sales. Theres some Management Alignment with the CEO investing personal capital, but they need to show more longterm commitment. Their Capital Allocation strategy could use a lot of improvement, too dependent on debt and diluting shareholders without strong returns. Interestingly, Analyst Sentiment is quite positive with higher price targets and some strong buy recommendations. Overall, the score is 3.610. Except profits are increasing even with higher rates and net interest expense still represents a very small of total profits. Which is because large cap companies refinanced when rates bottomed during Covid. And profits are only increasing nominally, as I will soon demonstrate. Forward earnings do not expect 300 growth in profits that is false. No, youre just unfamiliar with the numbers. Bloomberg analyst consensus estimated SP 500 Index earnings will end 2024 at 245, 2025 at 278, and 2026 at 302. This is equivalent to 9.7, 13.7, and 8.6 YoY respectively for an average of 10.3 growth per year. This is high but not implausible earnings growth tends to vary quite a bit over the shortterm. The problem is how the composition of said earnings would have to shake out. CPI inflation is expected to moderate towards its historical mean between 2024 and 2026, while real sales are projected to be slightly below the 25year average. Bloombergs model of future SP index earnings growth looks like this Nominal EPS growth 10.3 Real EPS 8.0 CPI YoY 2.3 Real Sales per Share 1.5 Real Earnings per Share 8.0 Real SP Profit Margin 6.5 Notably average profit margin growth from 20002024 is only 1.7. So yes, growth in profit margins is expected to increase around 300 of the historical mean over the next three years. Thus far companies are still delivering incredible growth. It really is not a bubble. As Ive tiresomely reminded people over and over again during the summer, real SP earnings have been rangebound essentially flat over the last 2 years At the end of the Q2 earnings season, Bloomberg revised from their yearlong SP earnings estimate from 243 to 240.64 and the Nasdaq dropped 3 to 663.13. The SPs drop was attributed to shrinking profit margins 13 12.9. Most analyst estimates concerning 20242026 earnings are erroneously based on the assumption 2022 was the new normal when it was just an aberration of fiscal policy. For example, EBIT margins are expected to grow to 18 by 2026 and stay there despite EBIT margins being 13 for the last two decades. EBIT margins reached 16 in 2022 but this was accomplished with 20 YoY nominal sales growth, which was boosted by 9 inflation. The same analysts expect sales growth to shrink in 2025 and rebound to 6 in 2026.

Its the worst month of the year, and its beginning to look a lot like last year for semis. Though INTC is up because its price is less than its book value. Apollo already cut a 5050 deal for an oversees deal, and private capital could be a modest savior for a company that might cease to exist in all but brand name, but the brand name is part of the book value. The thing is, designing a chip or a fabrication facility that makes a single thing, is a whole lot different from designing a fab that is already way behind schedule and might get off the ground by 2027, which is an eternity in AI years. What experience does Intel have working with lots of companies to secretly get their custom chips off the ground while making their own supposedly according to the CEO groundbreaking AI CPUs? TSMC is probably out because of the antitrust proAmerican, were going to build our own supply chains zeitgeist. Any company that sets itself up to compete with TSMC years from now, if they succeed, is stuck with the fact that they need TSMC now, when TSMC can pick and choose customers they want at the front of the line for advanced chips currently NVDA , QCOM, Apple, and broadcom. I own all of those except Apple. I scooped up prior to last quarters earnings then sold. Im anxious to own them in the next few weeks when the bears are betting with conviction. But, there is still a lot of private capital in highertier AI offerings like OpenAI which I think is a little overrated, maybe strawberry will change that, Anthropic, Perplexity, and Cerebras. Theres a lot more money in private capital than there used to be, and really wealthy investors seem to be stepping into a void that was formerly occupied by big banks. Anyway, it should be an exciting week, and its still a long time before the Fed meets later this month, which might finally help the highdebt companies in the R2K more than it helps the Mag 7. Im still long on the stocks that have impressive quarter over quarter earnings growth. Though they will go in and out of style, good growth and a good PEG which fails to describe most of the Nasdaq puts upward pressure on PE multiples for those who can wait.

If google offered me a house, free stocks, breakfast, lunch and dinner, free citizenship, I would run to work like a madman. Sure, because you arent desired enough by other companies. So that does probably seem impressive to you. But imagine, for the sake of the argument, that you begin with a different premise. Theoretically, there is a simple answer where those fringe benefits dont necessarily matter to someone if they already have enough compensation. In that world, obviously RTO just makes that talent battle even tougher for Googles downward trajectory.

I work in tech. I manage the accounting for a startup. Its all about messaging. When you enter an employment contract, its a package. Equity is how companies entice talent aside from the salary benefits question. Clearly it works on the talent side considering big tech manages to swoop up the best talent, even hoard it more often than not. When you change the explicit or implicit terms of the agreement, of course employees will be up in arms. Youre not handing them anything, youre simply exchanging money in various ways for their labor. On the question of office perks, it depends on how they were hired. Many employees were hired as remote or mostly remote. Some of those employees have families and often dont even need to be in office. No perks in the world could make them return to the office. Forcing it back on them is usually only done to trim headcount without having to layoff and pay severance packages. I get offered multiple lunches a week, free breakfast, alcohol, etc. and I still barely go in twice a week max because I simply have too much to do. Luckily my work gives me the flexibility to fuck off when I need to. I know exactly how much it costs to stock a company pantry per head in the local offices, and how much is spent on foodtravel, and I can tell you it barely makes a dent compared to the actual costs of running the firm. You dont know what youre talking about son.

Company Description The company engages in the design and development of technologies that enable connected in a range of communications and entertainment products and services, which are licensed to companies providing such products and services, including makers of wireless communications, consumer electronics, IoT devices, and cars and other motor vehicles, as well as providers of cloudbased services, such as video streaming. It designs and develops a range of innovations for use in digital cellular and wireless products and networks, including 2G, 3G, 4G, 5G, and IEEE 802related products and networks. The company also develops cellular technologies, such as technologies related to CDMA, TDMA, OFDMOFDMA, and MIMO for use in 2G, 3G, 4G, and 5G wireless networks, as well as mobile terminal devices and 3GPP technology portfolio in 5G, 5G, advanced and 6G, as well as technologies for automobiles, wearables, smart homes, drones, and other connected consumer electronic products. Its late cycle bull market investing. The Fed cuts rates which puts downward pressure on the DXY. Investors rush to buy metals and high dividend paying stocks. Metals because they are priced in USD and begin to appreciate. High dividend stocks start to become more attractive because US 10 year treasury rate yields decline. The idea is to rent these stocks for their move higher before we enter a full blown recession which creates demand destruction. Now VALE like a lot of commodity mining stocks pays a variable dividend based on annual income. Their next semiannual dividend will likely be lower than 0.54. So while the 0.54 dividend I will get on Sept 11th is nice, its not why I am buying more shares. I also opened a position in NTR which is agriculture miner of Potash, Nitrogen, and Phosphate. And I also bought more shares of my recently opened position in OXY. Good Luck.

My Earnings Trade I like MBUU right now and they have an earnings call next week. MBUU only has monthly options and not a ton of volume, and I want to use the earnings call to generate some premium and hopefully get assigned some more shares. So I sold the 32.50 put and the 30 put, both expiring 920. On the 32.50 Im getting 1.25 in premium, so I divide that into the capital required to make the trade 32.50, and I get 0.0385. Then I multiply that by 12 because this trade lasts one month and, in theory, I could do this trade or a similar trade on another company 12 times over the course of a year. That gets me 0.462, or an annualized return of 46. On the 30 put the annualized return is 28. If I get assigned Ill still have room for two more tranches after this in case MBUU continues further down. I also sold the call at 37.50 on half of the shares I own. My cost basis is 31.14 per share so Ill make money on both the premium and the sale if those get called away. I only did half because I want to own some shares if MBUU shoots up after earnings, but I also want to use the earnings call opportunity to reduce my cost basis per share as much as I can. Heres more detail on those trades. Ive found that using puts in tranches to enter companies I want to own long term that are trading at a price I want to own them at has been giving me a 20 return each of the last several years. Its a simple strategy without the risk of credit spreads, as long as its a company I actually want to own at the put price. Im interested in your thoughts.

Classic egg fallacy right there. You see, you think youre just getting a free dozen eggs, but actually the company is just removing a dozen eggs from their assets cartons, so the actual worth of the company has decreased. This is why on the exeggdate the value of the stock declines by about 12 eggs according to the spot price of eggs. Instead, I care more about the present value of all eggs this company will produce and store and deliver over the long haul. In fact, who is to say egg delivery is the best use of capital? Why cant they hatch the eggs and invest in their future harvest? Is that an implicit admission their return on egg is below their cost of capital? Or even better, why cant they buy back some eggs instead. Would the company like some eggs in this trying time? What does the Chief Egg Officer have to say about this?

Dont punish yourself. I did the same thing with Palo Alto and Meta. Have way less shares than Id prefer. Best thing to do is not force yourself to buy shares regardless of how much its running, its probably better to set aside a specific amount of your cash to buy the dip on that stock, when, it eventually has its breather. The hardest thing is trying to predict the bottom of the breather....5? 10 15? Then, when it drops to the target you have, you buy more from the amount that you set to the side What if it never drops to your dip target? Theres plenty of fish in the sea. You dont need to over focus on one particular stock, unless youre willing to bet your entire life savings on it or something. Otherwise, theres plenty of other tickers. You should probably have a top 7 that youre really into building positions in.

the assumptiosn into these models need to be udpated based on the nature of how companies make money over time and the types of companies As Ive tiresomely had to point out several times, this is a myth. The inverse correlation between 10year rolling CAPE and predicted future market returns has grown stronger, not weaker, over time due to more equitable market capitalization. The main reason why CAPE has been elevated since 2008 is abnormally low interest rates, which heavily skewed investor preference towards risk assets. When one compare yields across all fixedincome securities, including corporate bonds, to stock market returns over the last 15 years, the risk premium of stocks heavily outstrips the risk mitigation from including bonds in a portfolio. Anything below the 10year lost value versus inflation. first of alll we are more global vs the past. second of all, tech stocks are historically have higher PEs due to their ability to expand rapidly copying software is easy vs manufacturing new cars. These are cyclical factors, not secular. They also have no meaningful effect on PE, which is not tied to business performance or cost. PE is a measure of sentiment towards FCF and the future timespan one pays for it.

Not without reason. Deflation and deflationary spirals are really dangerous for an economy. Look back and find periods of deflation.... theyre generally around really bad economic times. 19291932 stands out as the biggest era of deflation. Deflation is a good thing. Inflation inevitably prices out the majority of market participants and creates a rentseeking economy that is fundamentally unproductive. The problem is by the nature of modern economic systems, deflation almost never happens gradually. It is usually severe, compressed, and the end result of rampant inflation. However, the Fed will not allow longterm deflation. Maintaining a higher level of inflation is essential for the government to pay off its debt its nominal cost can be covered by devaluing the currency.

We have averaged higher than 100 year average PEs for decades. Not really. The entire 2000s consisted of deflating the exorbitant multiples of the dot com bubble and as predicted by the inverse CAPE correlation between 10 year rolling average PE and returns average returns were zero. Until the end of the 2010s, we were sitting comfortably in the first standard deviation. Theres a standard misunderstanding that anything above the historical PE mean means the market is overvalued. Note the link I provided shows that future gains are relative, not negative, and need to be judged against riskfree assets. Which leads to the real reason PE levels have been elevated since 2010 zero interest rate policy. When fixedincome securities provide no yield and savings accounts dont even counteract inflation, people move their money into risk assets.

Id agree, depending on the cause of deflation. If it is due to efficiency gains, its definitely a plus. Ford automating assembly lines and producing really cheap cars...great for the consumer. Agree. But this is slow and usually results in longitudinal disinflation. If its deflation due to people not having enough money...thats where the spiral can happen. Which is the end result of inflation. Rapid deflation occurs when prices soar too quickly while additional monetary distribution is uneven and concentrated usually among the wealthy, where it becomes unproductive. Weve seen plenty of deflation due to technology. Consumer electronics are the best example lately. Ideally, wed find a way to build cheaper housing next... Not sure material or construction cost is the operating barrier. Regulation seems to be the main culprit.

Im not that thrilled about CELH earnings. I mean, the market share news is fantastic The Boca Raton, Floridabased company now has 11.5 control of the energy drink market, up from 8.7 a year ago, based on market share data from consumer data company Circana cited by Celsius Tuesday. Rivals Red Bull and Monster saw their share fall over the same period, with Monster down 1.6 percentage points and Red Bull 0.5, according to the Circana data. But 23 YoY growth is unimpressive. Maybe the comps are just tough. And if they are taking market share with this growth, it means the other beverage companies are also seeing a lull in sales growth. On the bright side, the forward PE has compressed dramatically. From 80s to like 30. I first started buying this stock around the low 50s, when it had a forward PE in the 70s90s. Were not too far away from that same share price with a 3rd of the PE, so they really did grow into the multiple. I first bought this stock expecting 40 revenue growth at a minimum to justify the multiple. That clearly is no longer the case but the multiple is also very fair now. So on this news, Im just sitting tight, not buying the dip or taking profits like I probably should have in the 90s.

Random thoughts The yen carry trade was one of the main drivers for the stock markets rise from November 2023 onwards. Traders dodged the Feds interest rate hikes by leveraging up in another currency running at effectively zero and was depreciating against the USD. Now that it is unraveling and will continue to unravel over the next several months, Im wondering where the liquidity will come from to restore the tech market to its previous heights. If hedge funds continue to unwind in long tech, will this need to come from the retail sector? The Treasury and Fed are currently at loggerheads. The huge Tbill issuance Yellen has directed to finance deficit spending directly conflicts with Powells dual mandate as shortterm securities do not absorb liquidity long enough to choke off money velocity which is how inflation works through the economy. With an inverted yield curve, it actually creates a lot of interest for those with sufficient capital in MMFs. If were assuming historical patterns persist, we havent hit the parabolic curve the meltup period of the A.I. craze yet. Even with this recent pullback, some catalyst will spark the final leg that restores investor sentiment and leads the retail sector to allin on tech.

Also, Amazon sales were up a lot. Despite all the negativity that made it drop 50 from ATH, the growth story is very intriguing. Main reasons for the drop that Ive found analyst downgrades, Pepsi lowering inventory, and lowered consumer spending. The Pepsi inventory was the only main concern but as time goes on, I think Celsius will be able to expand distribution channels and be a lot less reliant on Pepsi overall. Lastly Ive seen some mentions about health concerns?? I really dont know much about energy drinks but I feel like that would be an overall concern and not specific to Celsius. Also I havent been able to find any proper articles documenting healthy concerns.. just a few comments on reddit.

UPST Second Quarter 2024 Financial Highlights Revenue. Total revenue was 128 million, a decrease of 6 from the second quarter of 2023, and remained flat sequentially. Total fee revenue was 131 million, a decrease of 9 yearoveryear. Transaction Volume and Conversion Rate. 143,900 loans were originated, totaling 1.1 billion across our platform in the second quarter of 2024, down 6 from the same quarter of the prior year. Conversion on rate requests was 15 in the second quarter of 2024, up from 9 in the same quarter of the prior year. Income Loss from Operations. Income loss from operations was 55.5 million, down from 33.3 million in the same quarter of the prior year. Net Income Loss and EPS. GAAP net income loss was 54.5 million, down from 28.2 million in the second quarter of the prior year. Adjusted net income loss was 15.3 million, down from 5.4 million in the same quarter of the prior year. Accordingly, GAAP diluted earnings per share was 0.62, and diluted adjusted earnings per share was 0.17 based on the weightedaverage common shares outstanding during the quarter. Contribution Profit. Contribution profit was 76.1 million in the second quarter of 2024, down 21 yearoveryear, with a contribution margin of 58 compared to a 67 contribution margin in the same quarter of the prior year. Adjusted EBITDA. Adjusted EBITDA was 9.3 million, down from 11.0 million in the same quarter of the prior year. The second quarter 2024 adjusted EBITDA margin was 7 of total revenue, down from 8 in the same quarter of the prior year.

Lots of ways, but Vanguard isnt the broker for it, they simply dont let you do many types of trades because its for buy and hold investors. You can do so by directly shorting the futures, holding ETFs like SVXY 0.5x VIX ,directly short selling VXX 1x VIX, since VIX is a level of how expensive options are, you can also short VIX by selling puts and calls. I stress that if you dont know exactly what youre doing, as in you havent read the prospectus, understand how VIX is calculated, backtested various scenarios and how they affect the VIX, what the structure of VIX forward curve looks like and what it means, you shouldnt be doing this. Ok. For one advantage disadvantage to discuss with your friend is that with a buy and hold strategy you never have to pay taxes until you eventually sell hopefully when you are older But with his method he is going to have taxable events multiple times per year. Sure if he is way out gaining the sp500 then the added tax burden is worth And one question I didnt understand was are you saying when its at the bottom he buys a 2x leveraged sp500. But when it gets to the top band does he then sell the 2x leveraged sp500 and go to cash? Or does he sell it and buy a 2x leveraged bear shorting the sp500 until it hits the lower band again I personally think that second part would be nuts. Im all for buying at the bottom and riding it up. But I cannot imagine trying to find a sweet spot to short the sp500. Thats crazy
That literally is buy low sell high in fancy terms

sorry for the unclear formulation. He is not doing trading, its more long term. he specifically tries to minimize trades, maximize performance and minimize volatility. I think if you wanted to gently suggest something more technical to think about and are interested in engaging your coworker further in constructive discussion about it, you could probe about the particular percentages, moving averages, etc. involved in the method, and how those were found. As in other spaces, overfitting even a simple model or method to backtesting data can yield great results with sometimes just a few parameters, but future performance isnt at all guaranteed.

The annualized return rate on the SP 500 over the last 5 years is 14.873. Your buddy hasnt beat the market in 5 years. Also, it sounds like hes just saying to buy when he thinks the market is oversold and sell when its overbought, probably based on like the RSI or MACD or something. The problem is that those indicators can tell the wrong story sometimes, and you dont have all of the data from 2024 2065 to perfectly time your trades so you never lose.
on the other hand I also dont know what he should buy in that casesituation I would just go to 50 money market or Treasury fund like SGOV and 50 voo

his method was decent actually. At least as far as I can tell. He did a 2dimensional parameter variation to find the best durations for the two moving averages. And he then did another parameter variation with the percentage band. the second point I told him quite directly already. I did some machine learning for my masters thesis nothing financial though and I told him, that I really dislike the thoughtfeeling of having the testdata withing the training data to speak in ML terms. he said that he will do furher analysis on that which really necessary I think. he will apply his method of finding the parameters with the same criteria to different points in the historical data. And then use this result and apply it on the following years of the data. Which is not bad I think, but he has not done that yet. Maybe a question into a different direction that could calm my nerves about this. What do you think would be a realistic achieveable performance when investing into the 2x leveraged SP500 whilst having a strategy that is trying to avoid the crashes?

thanks for that! another reason why it is probably a bad strategy tbh as far as I can tell he is not using RSI or MACD, but purely moving average. But I dont know why he decided to do that. Maybe a question into a different direction that could reduce my concerns for this What do you think would be a realistic achieveable performance when investing into the 2x leveraged SP500 whilst having a strategy that is trying to avoid the crashes since like 1940?

That actually sounds like a pretty great and respectful discussion, then! It sounds like you two are hitting some excellent critical questions. Regarding keeping the traintest set separate although I wouldnt recommend deploying a lot of real money on it based on the results, a really interesting exploration that I think youre referring to trying too, or similar could be to optimize the parameters using data up through 2010 or so...and then see how the model performs from 20102024, especially around the financial crisis and COVID. And then you could do kind of the opposite, maybe training on 20042024 and then running it back to 1940. Theres all sorts of fun to be had! Regarding your last paragraph...its very difficult to expose yourself to worthwhile 2x leverage and also avoid significant drawdowns during market downturns unless youre assuming you can time exits and entries very well. I think if you could find a lowslippage means to get 1.52x leverage on a significant portion of your account, perhaps have a small amount of uncorrelated or negative beta assets in there too, and if past performance really were indicative of what well see in the future, Id guess from my armchair that you could maybe see 812 real returns on average over a very long period. But youd almost certainly have to deal with the tradeoff of higher volatility at some smaller timescales.

Leveraged index funds are not as simple as if i put in my money it goes up twice as fast I wouldnt touch a leveraged index fund. I would put most of my money into a broad index and then use the rest to buy good companies. Use the crashes to buy more shares for cheaper. There will be crashes, Ive seen a bunch of them, why are you trying to avoid them? Covid was horrific, but you know who didnt lose a dime during that? The people who bought and held. The market always recovers. Youre young, you have like 40 years of investing in front of you, just let compound interest and time do their thing. Dont be like your coworker and try to get crafty, youll spin your tires and at BEST break even with people just going with the market. Buy and hold in the SP has been THE winning strategy for 150 years.

My head is starting to hurt. Been some exhausting conversations. It definitely is a respectful discission. We have not talked about specific timeframes to testoptimize the parameters for. But yeah, can definitely be done and would be interesting. What I think would be interesting and I told him that he should investigate is the following. Try to generate your parameters with 10 years of historic training data throughout the data he has and see if the parameters changeshow a trend or converge towards a value. And in addition to that use all the data from 1940 to 1950, then from 1940 to 1960 and so on. Continuously increasing the training data and always evaluating for the next 10 years. And see if the resulting parameters converge towards a value or fluctuate. This would showproof somehow his method works not just for training data but also for test data and that the market is not changing so fast, that historical data is unuseable. He still has significant downturns and specifically looks and tries to avoid them. But he is aware that they are not unavoidable. That is why he is hesitant do enter right now, because the sp500 is at an ATH. so investing now would most likely result in a downturn. Or do you disagree? To be honest, I understand next to little of the last paragraph. But sounds like trying to reduce riskoverexposure to one asset give me some slack with the terminology here. I am not an expert. His evaluations of the historical data, which is by no means an guarantee on future performance, that we agree upon, show 22ish percent annual.

I personally am in this mindset. But good companiesfunds and hold. But he is smartcreativesometimes bored and wants to optimize performance. That is why he had the idea of using leverage whilst still minimizing volatility. Thanks for your great feedback!

Sometimes leverage makes sense. I will admit to using some in 2020 to maximize gains during the fire sale. It was nothing I couldnt pay for with my other holdings and rates were quite low. You should give yourself the option. At your age volatility is no big thing but if you want a less volatile VOO I would argue thats called BRK.B. It will fall sometimes but that triggers buybacks so its a bit more resilient.

It could discourage other customers from using SpaceXs launch services in the future.

Yes but this strategy changes day to day. The only strategy that I use that never changes, is I stick with either calls or puts. A lot of people try to trade both the upside and the down side. I dont do that. If Im trading calls, I am trading ONLY calls on that day. Trying to trade both calls and puts in the same day will fuck you up big time. Right now, I been only trading calls, havent touched puts in weeks, due to various reasons. Even if I expect a deep red day, Ill still buy calls and exit quickly. My point is, dont trade calls in puts on the same day, pick a direction and stick with it. Also, the most important thing to trading is determine sentiment. You have to be able to gauge sentiment correctly

Typical Bandwidth Fashion. report good / expected revenues and earnings numbers... and drop like a rock. Rinse & Repeat.  Dead Money Here, For Several Years.

Intel is cutting their dividend AND laying off 15K workers and they drop 30%!  That is what I would call a bad quarterly call!  I get the negative sentiment of the overall market... it can be fickle.  But dropping a price 30% after they beat guidance with no negative news?!?  That should be the definition of an overreaction!
This could be an overreaction

How do most telecoms/infrastructure companies go bust? Its debt.

When you borrow debt are liabilities counted against you? Yes.

Will that effect the rate you get? Yes.

How much do we reward employees for these great spending moves? How about 40-50m a year or lets keep diluting shareholders at an accelerated rate of 10% a year.

The lease liabilities were expected, as that new office was years in the making. The lease is also like 20 years, so that $220m is hardly a balance sheet concern. They will clear $700m in revenue this year, and you worry about the $11m lease cost for the year?

Debt matters especially these days. They have about 30m of 2026 and 250m of 2028 notes outstanding, this is expected. Whats not expected is 220m of lease liabilities that they now have to put on their balance sheet because of their new build office in NC. So that means the last two years of paying debt did not amount to much balance sheet wise. Management continue to disappoint shareholders. Looks like another year at least of waiting for them to pay down more debt or to actually make some real profits.
